questions.question_text: A wireless network has two RF groups where Cisco WLCs are joined. APs are associated with different controllers using the round-robin approach. Rogue containment must be deployed in all controllers, but the network must not be affected by any RRM neighbor packets sent by friendly APs. Which AP authentication protection type must be enabled?

comments.content:
Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
Option A: AP Wireless Protection Rules

This is not a valid feature for preventing rogue APs or managing RRM neighbor packets.

Option B: AP Security

This is a general term and not a specific feature for this scenario.

Option C: AP Access Control

This is not the correct feature for managing rogue containment or RRM neighbor packets.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
In a wireless network with multiple RF groups and controllers, AP Authentication is the feature that must be enabled to ensure that rogue containment is deployed without being affected by RRM (Radio Resource Management) neighbor packets sent by friendly APs. Here's why:

AP Authentication:
This feature ensures that only authorized APs are allowed to join the network. It prevents rogue APs from connecting to the network and ensures that RRM neighbor packets are only sent by trusted, authenticated APs.

Why It’s Necessary:

Rogue containment relies on the ability to distinguish between authorized (friendly) APs and unauthorized (rogue) APs.

By enabling AP Authentication, the network ensures that only legitimate APs participate in RRM and other network operations, preventing interference from rogue APs.

choices.D: config flow add monitor Export_to_Prime_Infrastructure exporter AVC_test
choices.B: config flow create exporter Export_to_Prime_Infrastructure 10.20.30.6 port 9991
choices.E: config flow add monitor AVC_test exporter Export_to_Prime_Infrastructure
choices.C: config flow create exporter Export_to_Prime_Infrastructure 10.20.30.6 port 8080
choices.A: config flow add monitor AVC_test record ipv4_client_app_flow_record

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
To ensure that NetFlow data is exported from the AireOS controllers to Cisco Prime Infrastructure, the following configurations must be applied:

Add the Flow Record to the Flow Monitor:

The command config flow add monitor AVC_test record ipv4_client_app_flow_record associates the flow record (ipv4_client_app_flow_record) with the flow monitor (AVC_test). This ensures that the monitor collects the correct data.

Add the Exporter to the Flow Monitor:

The command config flow add monitor AVC_test exporter Export_to_Prime_Infrastructure associates the exporter (Export_to_Prime_Infrastructure) with the flow monitor (AVC_test). This ensures that the collected data is sent to the specified exporter (Cisco Prime Infrastructure).

comments.content:
Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
Option B: config flow create exporter Export_to_Prime_Infrastructure 10.20.30.6 port 9991

This command creates a new exporter with port 9991, but the exhibit shows that the exporter is already configured with port 8080. This option is unnecessary and incorrect.

Option C: config flow create exporter Export_to_Prime_Infrastructure 10.20.30.6 port 8080

This command creates a new exporter with port 8080, but the exhibit shows that the exporter is already configured. This option is redundant and incorrect.

Option D: config flow add monitor Export_to_Prime_Infrastructure exporter AVC_test

This command is incorrect because it attempts to add the exporter to the monitor in reverse order. The correct syntax is to add the exporter to the monitor, not the monitor to the exporter.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
A, E are right answers

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A customer implements AVC on the AireOS controllers. All of the NetFlow data is configured for export to Cisco Prime Infrastructure to be analyzed for a specified period. During testing, no data is reported from the controllers. Which two configurations must be applied for the data to be exported? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
In a setup where guest tunneling is used, the anchor controller is the device that performs the RADIUS authentication requests for the web authentication method. Here's why:

Guest Tunneling:

In this setup, the foreign controller (the controller to which the client initially connects) tunnels the guest traffic to the anchor controller (the controller responsible for handling guest access).

The anchor controller is the device that interacts with Cisco ISE for authentication and authorization.

Web Authentication:

When central web authentication is used, the anchor controller acts as the RADIUS client and sends authentication requests to Cisco ISE.

Cisco ISE processes these requests and returns the appropriate response (e.g., granting or denying access).

comments.content:
Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
Option A: Foreign controller

The foreign controller handles the initial connection and tunnels the traffic to the anchor controller. It does not perform RADIUS authentication for web authentication.

Option B: Authentication server

Cisco ISE is the authentication server, not the device performing the RADIUS authentication requests. The anchor controller sends requests to ISE.

Option D: APs

Access Points (APs) forward traffic to the controller but do not handle RADIUS authentication for web authentication.

questions.question_text:
An SSID is set up with central web authentication using Cisco ISE. The new SSID uses guest tunneling from the foreign controller to the anchor controller.

Which device must be configured on ISE as the one performing the RADIUS authentication requests for the web authentication method?

An engineer must implement multicast on an AireOS WLC v8.2 that has 200 LWAPs connected. Reliable reception is a main requirement of this implementation. Which wireless configuration must be performed?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Disabling lower mandatory data rates ensures that multicast traffic is transmitted at higher rates, reducing airtime consumption and improving reliability. This prevents multicast packets from being sent at the lowest basic rate, which could negatively impact performance, especially in large deployments with 200 lightweight APs.

Selected Answer: D
To implement multicast on an AireOS WLC with reliable reception as a main requirement, the engineer should disable lower mandatory data rates. Here's why:

Multicast and Data Rates:

Multicast traffic is sent at the lowest mandatory data rate configured on the WLAN. If lower data rates (e.g., 1 Mbps, 2 Mbps) are enabled, multicast traffic will be sent at these slower rates, which can lead to poor performance and unreliable reception.

By disabling lower mandatory data rates, multicast traffic is sent at higher data rates, improving reliability and performance.

Impact on Coverage:

Disabling lower data rates reduces the coverage area of the APs, but this trade-off is necessary to ensure reliable multicast reception. Clients must be closer to the APs to maintain a connection, but the multicast traffic will be more reliable.

comments.content:
Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
Option A: Increase the coverage cell.

Increasing the coverage cell size would allow clients to connect from farther away, but it does not address the issue of reliable multicast reception. In fact, it could worsen multicast performance.

Option B: Decrease the coverage cell.

Decreasing the coverage cell size would force clients to be closer to the APs, but it does not directly improve multicast reliability. Disabling lower data rates is a more effective solution.

Option C: Disable higher mandatory data rates.

Disabling higher data rates would force multicast traffic to be sent at even lower rates, which would degrade performance and reliability.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Disable higher mandatory data rates

questions.question_text: An engineer configures an ACL on a Cisco WLC v8.7. The engineer must control Pv4 traffic to the CPU of the controller. Which rules should be added at the top of the ACL to control IPv4 traffic?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
When configuring an ACL on a Cisco WLC to control IPv4 traffic to the CPU, it is critical to allow mobility traffic to ensure proper communication between controllers in a mobility group. Here's why:

Mobility Ports (16666, 16667, and 16668):

These ports are used for communication between controllers in a mobility group. Blocking these ports can disrupt controller-to-controller communication, leading to issues such as client roaming failures.

Therefore, the ACL must include rules to allow traffic on these ports at the top of the ACL to ensure uninterrupted mobility operations.

comments.content:
Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
Option B: Deny mobility ports 16666, 16667, and 16668.

Denying these ports would disrupt mobility communication between controllers, leading to roaming issues and network instability.

Option C: Deny RRM ports 12124–12125 and 12134–12135.

These ports are used for Radio Resource Management (RRM) communication. While controlling RRM traffic might be necessary in some cases, it is not the top priority when configuring an ACL for CPU traffic control.

Option D: Allow RRM ports 12124–12125 and 12134–12135.

While allowing RRM traffic is important, it is not as critical as allowing mobility traffic. Mobility traffic must be prioritized to ensure seamless roaming and controller communication.

discussion.content:
Before you apply ACL rules, ensure that you have explicitly set the following RRM ports to allow in the CPU ACL:
12124-12125
12134-12135
Also ensure that you add these ACL rules specifically at the top of the ACL list.
If you do not set these RRM ports to allow, the ports are blocked by default
